Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

using the following format:

By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
Thanks, LGTM!
maintainer merge
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by faenuccio.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9805490157/job/27075252307)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9805490157/job/27075252870)
Thanks!
Thanks!

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion simpa [‚Üê mul_sum, hn] using hf ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion rw [‚Üê Nat.sum_div hfdvd, hfsum, Nat.mul_div_cancel_left _ hn.bot_lt] ```

```suggestion
      exact fun hi _ ‚Ü¶ ha.2 i hi
```
provides... "the definition and the main properties of", or something like this? Also, can you point to the main declarations of the file?
Can we add a link to the file where the `HasAntidiagonal` class is defined?

```suggestion
/-- The finset of functions `Œπ ‚Üí‚ÇÄ Œº` with support contained in `s` and sum equal to `n`. -/
```

```suggestion
  ext f; simp [finsuppAntidiag, ‚Üê DFunLike.coe_fn_eq (g := f), eq_comm]
```
Or is a precise reason to explicitely remove `mem_piAntidiag`?
Oh, it's not needed anymore. Well spotted

```suggestion
  eq_empty_of_forall_not_mem (by simp [@eq_comm _ 0, hn.symm])
```

As in the other file, can you point to the main results, or main API things that a user might want to use when stumbling upon this file? And add a link to the definition of the `HasAntidiagonal` class?

```suggestion
choosing an identification `s ‚âÉ Fin s.card` and proving that the end result does not depend on that
```
Also, can you say which is this result, and add to it (below) a bit of doc along the lines "this lemma/thm proves that ..."?

```suggestion
  eq_empty_of_forall_not_mem (by simp [@eq_comm _ 0, hn.symm])
```
I am not sure what to suggest about the "of_ne_zero" vs "ne_zero", but I observe that in the previous lemma there is no `of` and here yes; I believe they should be uniform.

That "discrepancy" is perfectly in line with the naming convention:
* In `piAntidiag_empty_zero : piAntidiag (‚àÖ : Finset Œπ) (0 : Œº) = {0}`, the `0` appears in the LHS, hence there is no `of`
* In `piAntidiag_empty_of_ne_zero (hn : n ‚â† 0) : piAntidiag (‚àÖ : Finset Œπ) n = ‚àÖ`, the `n ‚â† 0` appears in an hypothesis, hence there is a `of`.
Is there any of all these lemma that might/should be marked `aesop`?
Highly unclear to me. I would rather not for now, out of lack of application (and since adding aesop rules incurs a cost on every future aesop call). We can easily change our mind in a later PR
`equiv` or `eq`?
I did want to go with `equiv`, but you're right it's a terrible name
See my comment above to see if we need something like `of_zero`.
Same reply as above
A bit of doc fot this notation, so users see what it means?
I do not understand how Lean can see that `univ` is the `univ` of `Fintype k`, but it does! Do you have an explanation (and perhaps one that can be put in a bit of doc for other future users)?

Oh that's simple: We have `Finset.Nat.antidiagonalTuple (k : ‚Ñï) (n : ‚Ñï) : Finset (Fin k ‚Üí ‚Ñï)`, so the RHS here has type `Finset (Fin k ‚Üí ‚Ñï)` and Lean easily unifies that with `Finset (Œ± ‚Üí ‚Ñï)`.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Antidiagonal as a `Finset (Œπ ‚Üí Œº)`
